topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Varun Parmar (CPO of Miro), frames curiosity about Miro’s product culture and competitive success, and previews topics they’ll cover.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for Miro, Braintrust, and later Linear, including product pitches and promo URLs.

topics.title: Global footprint and cross-cultural product collaboration
topics.summary: Varun explains Miro’s globally distributed setup (product org largely in Europe, GTM worldwide) and how it forces strong internal empathy and cross-functional teamwork.

topics.title: Practicing empathy through better product questions
topics.summary: They discuss how asking “what insight led you here?” in reviews and 1:1s builds empathy and ensures decisions are grounded in customer and internal stakeholder context.

topics.title: Design Sprints and the Talktrack product decision
topics.summary: Varun shares how Miro uses 5-day Design Sprints to validate hypotheses quickly, illustrated by Talktrack’s approach (syncing board movement + video) driven by user insight about collaboration, not just communication.

topics.title: Competing in a crowded whiteboard collaboration market
topics.summary: Varun outlines Miro’s differentiation: a team-centric lens (not single-persona tools), broad industry applicability beyond digital design, unique workshop/ritual capabilities, and community as a growth engine.

topics.title: Team size and persona-based product org structure
topics.summary: Varun gives org context (1,800 employees; large PM org) and explains Miro’s “streams” organized primarily by persona (e.g., Enterprise, Platform) plus horizontal areas like Growth, Infra, and Data/AI.

topics.title: Avoiding persona silos with AMPED and reviews
topics.summary: They cover how Miro keeps a holistic product experience despite persona streams: AMPED cross-functional teams (Analytics, Marketing, Product, Engineering, Design), transparent product work via Slack, formal product reviews for big bets, and enterprise checklists baked into feature development.

topics.title: Why product marketing is embedded in product teams
topics.summary: Varun explains the rationale for including product marketing in AMPED: sharper positioning, packaging, and competitive differentiation so shipped features translate into market impact and sales clarity.

topics.title: Competition as the key variable in growth
topics.summary: Varun argues company growth often tracks what competitors enable or constrain (distribution, pricing, “good enough” product) and advises being explicit about differentiation and ecosystem positioning rather than ignoring competitors.

topics.title: Products always get better or worse
topics.summary: Varun shares a core philosophy: every release moves you forward or backward versus competitors in customers’ minds, like chess moves, which forces clarity on what to build and why.

topics.title: Speed philosophy: be first to hit the brick wall
topics.summary: Varun advocates moving fast in competitive, uncertain spaces to learn sooner than others—prioritizing rapid iteration to discover wrong paths early and adjust direction.

topics.title: Creating urgency by removing blockers
topics.summary: They discuss why teams slow down (technical/org/prioritization blockers) and Varun’s approach: encourage PMs to raise blockers quickly and make leadership responsible for fast resolution to create a virtuous cycle of faster delivery.

topics.title: Operating system: deliver customer value faster, high quality
topics.summary: Varun describes Miro’s product motto and how it’s operationalized: value measured by usage/metric movement, speed tracked via cycle times, and quality reinforced through monthly design leadership reviews that classify shipped work as high-quality or not.

topics.title: Measuring velocity with stage gates and cycle times
topics.summary: Varun explains Miro’s staged product process (strategy, problem, solution, post-ship metric impact), sizing (small/medium/large), and using shared cycle-time data to benchmark teams, learn from outliers, and improve throughput via product ops/product excellence.
